Graphical abstract The optimized 2-MoS2/CoS/NF heterojunction is used as the anode and cathode simultaneously, revealing a low voltage of 1.517 V at 10 mA cm−2, which exhibits robust electrocatalytic activity. The utilization of non-noble metal catalysts with robust and highly efficient electrocatalytic activity for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) are extremely important for the large-scale implementation of renewable energy devices. Integration of bifunctional electrocatalysts on both anode and cathode electrodes remains a significant challenge. Herein, we report on a novel and facile strategy to construct the ordered and aligned MoS2 nanosheet-encapsulated metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) derived hollow CoS polyhedron, in-situ grown on a nickel foam (NF). The starfish-like MoS2/CoS/NF heterojunctions were formed due to the ordered growth of the material caused by NF substrate. The optimized 2-MoS2/CoS/NF heterojunction exhibits robust bifunctional electrocatalytic activity with a low overpotential of 67 and 207 mV toward the HER and OER at 10 mA cm−2, and the long-term stability, which exceeds most of the reported bifunctional electrocatalysts. Such high electrocatalytic performance arises due to the synergistic effect between the MoS2 and CoS phases across the interface, the abundant active sites, as well as the hierarchical pore framework, which collectively enhance the mass and electron transfer during the reactions. The work provides a promising approach to fabricating bifunctional catalysts with custom-designed heterojunctions and remarkable performance for applications in electrochemical energy devices and related areas. Keywords Heterojunction Bifunctional catalysts HER OER 1 Introduction The increasing demand for clean and renewable fuel resources has drawn worldwide attention to sustainable and efficient energy technologies [1]. Hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) is a beneficial approach to achieving high-purity hydrogen production from abundant water resources [2,3]. Oxygen evolution reaction (OER) plays a critical role in water splitting. However, the OER suffers from sluggish kinetics and the associated large overpotentials, resulting in low efficiency in numerous energy systems [4]. In order to reduce the costs, these energy systems urgently need to integrate different reactions into one unit. Therefore, it is highly desirable to develop efficient, low-cost and bi-functional electrocatalysts that can drive both HER and OER reactions. Although some commercial catalysts (such as Pt/C and RuO2) have the highest electrocatalytic activity for the aforementioned reactions, the cost and scarcity of these noble metal-based catalysts seriously restrict their large-scale applications [5–7]. Hence, the development of a high-efficiency, durable and non-precious metal electrocatalysts is urgently desired for large-scale implementation of clean and sustainable energy systems. Recently, researchers have developed and fabricated a series of low-cost electrocatalysts, including transition-metal chalcogenides [8] metallic oxide [9], metal nitrides [10], metal carbides [11], and metal phosphides [12]. Particularly, the transition metal sulfides have broad application prospects because of their low cost and ease of preparation [13]. For the metal sulfides, the electronegative S atoms on the surface of catalysts serve as active sites for adsorption and desorption of H atoms, which is similar to the P atoms in metal phosphides. However, because of the negatively charged P sites in metal phosphides, and it is easy to form a passivation layer on the surface of the electrocatalyst, thereby completely blocking the electrocatalytic reaction [13]. While the metal nitride has a limited number of electrochemically active sites in bulk, which can severely restrict its catalytic and energy storage efficiency in practical applications [14]. Additionally, the S atoms in metal sulfides can be combined with transition metal cations to form hydrated ions for improved water molecule dissociation. Therefore, it is significant to prepare a kind of low cost and high efficiency bifunctional transition metal sulfide for overall water splitting. Among the transition metal sulfides, the molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) is extensively employed in HER electrocatalysts due to its suitable band structure, high energy conversion efficiency and plentiful exposed active sites. Nevertheless, the catalytic activity of MoS2 is strongly related to its electronic structure [15]. A great deal of research work has been undertaken on regulating the electronic structure of the MoS2 to improve electrocatalytic activity, such as heterojunction interface tuning [16], atomic doping [17], defect engineering [18], and modification of the phase structure [19]. Interface engineering is an effective method for architecture composite heterojunction electrocatalysts. Recently, Feng et al. prepared 3D 1 T-MoS2/CoS2 heterostructure via interface engineering regarded as an appealing material for HER, which delivered a low overpotential of 71 mV at 10 mA cm−2 [20]. Liu and co-workers synthesized in-plane intergrowth CoS2/MoS2 ultrathin nanosheet via one-step pyrolytic sulfurization of a small-sized Co/Mo-MOF precursor, which showed an overpotential of 75 mV at 10 mA cm−2 [21]. Zhao et al. successfully synthesized CoS/NC@MoS2 hollow spheres, which exhibited outstanding electrochemical performance in HER with an overpotential of 77 mV to reach the current density of 10 mA cm−2 [22]. Huang and co-workers reported a CeO2-embedded mesoporous CoS/MoS2 as a highly efficient and robust OER electrocatalyst, which displayed excellent OER electrocatalytic performance in alkaline with an overpotential of 247 mV at 10 mA cm−2 [23]. It further indicates that the designed interfaces of MoS2 play a significant role in improving the catalytic activity of MoS2 composites. In spite of possessing such abundant catalytic sites, MoS2-based heterostructures as high-efficiency bifunctional materials are still rarely applied simultaneously for HER and OER. Therefore, the structurally tailored and rational design of MoS2 edge active sites is the key factor in the preparation of efficient electrocatalysts. Zeolitic imidazole frameworks (ZIFs) were often used as appropriate precursors for the preparation of structure-tailored composite materials due to their large specific surface area, high porosity, and intricate crystalline structure [24]. The adjustable structural features of ZIFs provide effective platforms to construct functional composite materials for applications in hydrogen storage and separation [25], sensors [26], catalytic reactions [27] and other fields. Hollow cobalt sulfide with polyhedral structure can be prepared by direct sulphurization of ZIFs. In such hollow polyhedron frameworks, the large specific surface area and micropores structure can promote the diffusion and mass transport of ionic species. In addition, the obtained hollow CoS derivatives can be used to effectively regulate the microstructure. This structure will directly influence the exposure of active sites because of the positive correlation between the organic ligands and metal ions clusters, which make ZIFs highly suitable for the design of diverse multifunctional materials. However, for water splitting electrodes, the electrocatalyst is usually combined with a polymer and then dispersed on the conductive substrate. The use of non-reactive insulating binders inevitably leads to a decrease in the catalytic activity of the electrode and an increase in the overpotential, which is obviously disadvantageous for the water splitting kinetics. Therefore, it is urgent to construct a binder-free, self-supporting electrode based on efficient bifunctional electrocatalysts. Typically, such three-dimensional structures can be formed in situ by catalysts on metal supports such as a commercial nickel foam. Herein, we report an efficient and stable electrocatalyst through the interface engineering of novel MoS2/CoS heterostructures by room temperature growth, vulcanization process and subsequent hydrothermal reaction. In the 3D starfish-like MoS2/CoS/NF heterostructures, the outer MoS2 nanosheets are decorated on the surface of the inner hollow CoS polyhedron frameworks, and the abundant interfaces are generated between the MoS2 and CoS. Interestingly, in the interior hollow CoS polyhedral surface, the MoS2 nanosheets grow in the angular direction of the hollow CoS polyhedron. This effect is mainly caused by the NF support, ensuring the ordered growth of the composite material. As a result, the optimized 2-MoS2/CoS/NF heterostructures possess remarkable HER (overpotential of 67 mV at 10 mA cm−2), OER (overpotentials of 207 mV at 10 mA cm−2) activity and durability in 1 M KOH solution, being superior to the noble metal-based catalysts. Supported with density functional theory (DFT) calculations, the above results indicate that the established interfaces between MoS2 and CoS phases promote adsorption of hydrogen-containing and oxygen-containing intermediates, thereby further improving the HER and OER performance. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials The sodium molybdate (Na2MoO4·2H2O) and cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O) were purchased from Sinopharm Group. The 2-methylimidazole (2MeIm, C4H6N2, 99.0%) and thioacetamide were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich Co. ltd. The potassium hydroxide (KOH), methyl alcohol and absolute ethyl alcohol were purchased from Shanghai Maclean Biochemical Technology Co., ltd. All reagents were used without further purification. 2.2 Sample preparation 2.2.1 Preparation of the ZIF-67/NF and ZIF-67 At first, the nickel foam (NF, 1 cm × 1 cm, thickness: 1 mm) was cleaned with1 M HCl, absolute ethyl alcohol and deionized water with ultrasonication for 10 min to remove the surface oxides and oil stains, respectively. The Co(NO3)2·6H2O of 291.03 mg and dimethylimidazole of 82.1 mg were dissolved uniformly in methanol solution. Afterward, the two solutions were mixed, and the cleaned NF was added to the above mixed solution. Subsequently, the homogeneous mixture was kept at room temperature for 24 h. The ZIF-67/NF was acquired via washing in ethyl alcohol and drying at 60 °C. Similarly, the ZIF-67 was synthesized on the basis of the above method except for the addition of the NF. 2.2.2 Synthesis of CoS/NF and CoS powder The CoS/NF was obtained by vulcanizing the precursor ZIF-67/NF. Specifically, the thioacetamide of the 140.87 mg was dispersed in an ethanol solution of 30 mL. And then, the mixed solution was transferred to a 50 mL sealed reactor and the prepared ZIF-67/NF was added at 150 °C for 2 h. After that, the CoS/NF was obtained by washing and drying. As well, the CoS powder was obtained using ZIF-67 instead of ZIF-67/NF according to the above procedure. 2.2.3 Synthesis of MoS2/CoS/NF, MoS2/NF, MoS2/CoS powder, MoS2 powder The Na2MoO4·2H2O (241.95 mg) and thiourea (304.48 mg) were dissolved in a 30 ml aqueous solution and mixed uniformity. Following, the mixture was transferred to the sealed reactor and the prepared CoS/NF above was added at 180 °C for 10 h. After the reaction, the 1-MoS2/CoS/NF products were obtained by washing in deionized water and drying at 60 °C. Similarly, a series of MoS2/CoS/NF heterojunction catalysts with different MoS2 content were prepared when the feeding mass ratio of the Na2MoO4·2H2O and the CoS precursor prepared above were 0.5, 1, 2, and 3 times, respectively. The prepared catalysts are denoted as 0.5-MoS2/CoS/NF, 1-MoS2/CoS/NF, 2-MoS2/CoS/NF and 3-MoS2/CoS/NF. The MoS2/NF was prepared by replacing CoS/NF with NF via the hydrothermal method. Similarly, the CoS, MoS2 and MoS2/CoS were obtained in the powder form based on the above preparation method except for the addition of NF. According to the before and after the reaction, the fabricated MoS2/CoS on NF with the loading amount was about 4 mg. 2.2.4 Preparation of RuO2 and 20 wt% Pt/C powders catalysts For comparison, the RuO2 and 20 wt% Pt/C powders loaded on NF (1 cm2) were also synthesized. Specifically, the RuO2 or Pt/C powders of 10 mg were dispersed to the Nafion solution (20 μL), deionized water (250 μL) and ethanol (230 μL) mixed solution, and then the solution was ultrasound for 30 minutes to form a homogeneous ink. Afterward, the ink was dropped on the NF surface and made the loading amount to 4 mg. The samples were further dried to obtain the RuO2/NF and Pt/C/NF. 2.3 Materials characterization The morphologies and microstructures of the prepared products were tested by field-emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM, JEOL, Japan) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM-2010, Japan). The X-ray diffraction (XRD) was used to identify the crystal phases of the products on a Rigaku Ultima IV X-ray diffractometer. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) can be used to analyze the elemental chemical states of the catalyst materials. The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms are obtained to test the specific surface area and pore structure at 77 K using automatic volumetric adsorption equipment (Belsorp-Max). 2.4 Electrochemical measurements The electrochemical experiment was carried out using a typical three-electrode cell in 1 M KOH electrolytes (pH = 14). The carbon rod, Hg/HgO (saturated KOH, 1 M) electrode and the as-prepared samples served as the counter electrode, the reference electrode, and the working electrode (1 cm × 1 cm), respectively. The linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curve was obtained at a scan rate of 2 mV s−1 from −0.8 to −1.7 V vs. RHE for HER, and from 0 to 0.9 V vs. RHE for OER in alkaline media, respectively. The scan range and scan rate of LSV curve before and after 3000 CV were the same parameters with the LSV curve of HER and OER. All the results were obtained without iR-compensation. The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements were performed by applying an AC voltage in a frequency range from 100 kHz to 0.1 Hz with an alternating current amplitude of 5 mV. The chronoamperometry was carried out to study the catalyst stability. The test was carried out at −0.07 V (vs. RHE) for HER and 1.437 V (vs. RHE) for OER continuous operation for 22 h. Cyclic voltammograms (CV) taken at various scan rates (20, 40, 60, 80 and 100 mV s−1) were recorded in narrow potential windows from 0.02 to 0.12 V and 0.82 to 1.02 V vs. RHE in alkaline media for HER and OER, respectively. Besides, the MoS2 is proposed to experience significant oxidation during OER, and dissolve in the electrocatalyst. Therefore, the CV is performed to stabilize the electrocatalyst before recording the OER polarization curves, and then the fresh alkaline electrocatalyst should be used to obtain LSV curves. All potentials were converted to a reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) based on the Eq. (1). (1) E RHE = E Hg / HgO + 0.095 + 0.059 pH 2.5 Density functional theory (DFT) calculations DFT calculations were performed in the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP). A spin-polarized GGA PBE functional, all-electron plane-wave basis sets with an energy cutoff of 520 eV, and a projector augmented wave (PAW) method were adopted. A (3 × 3 × 1) Monkhorst-Pack mesh was used for the Brillouin-zone integrations to be sampled. The conjugate gradient algorithm was used in the optimization. In terms of modeling, the atomistic model of the CoS, MoS2 and 2-MoS2/CoS was developed based on the crystal structure measured by the XRD, and all the models were optimized. In addition, the exposed surface was determined by HRTEM. In other words, in the modeling process, we selected the (100) crystal plane of the catalyst as the active site to study the catalyst performance. The convergence threshold was set 1 × 10−5 eV in total energy and 0.02 eV Å−1 in force on each atom. The adsorption energy change (ΔE abs) was determined by Eq. (2). (2) Δ E abs = E total - E slab - E mol where E total is the total energy for the adsorption state, E slab is the energy of pure surface, E mol is the energy of adsorption molecule. The free energy change (ΔG) for adsorptions were determined by Eq. (3). (3) Δ G = E total - E slab - E mol + Δ E ZPE - T Δ S where E total is the total energy for the adsorption state, E slab is the energy of pure surface, E mol is the energy of adsorption molecule, ΔE ZPE is the zero-point energy change and ΔS is the entropy change. As the vibrational entropy of H* in the adsorbed state is small, the entropy of adsorption of 1/2 H2 is Eq. (4). (4) S H ≈ - 0.5 S 0 H 2 where S 0H2 is the entropy of H2 in the gas phase at the standard conditions. Therefore, the overall corrections were taken as in Eq. (5). (5) Δ G H ∗ = E total - E slab - E H 2 / 2 + 0 . 24 eV where E H2 is the energy of H2 in gas phase. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure of the catalyst The preparation process of the MoS2/CoS heterostructures on nickel foam (NF) is shown in Scheme 1 . Specifically, first, the ZIF-67 is in-situ grown on NF and stands for 24 h at room temperature to obtain ZIF-67/NF. Then, the ZIF-67/NF is further vulcanized to obtain hollow CoS polyhedron frameworks on NF. Finally, the hollow CoS modified by MoS2 is obtained MoS2/CoS/NF heterojunction via the hydrothermal method. To discuss the effect of the nickel foam support substrate on the catalyst morphology, the microstructure of the 2-MoS2/CoS/NF heterojunction electrocatalyst is characterized by SEM images. In the 3D 2-MoS2/CoS/NF heterostructures, the outer MoS2 nanosheets are decorated on the surface of the hollow CoS polyhedron frame. On the one hand, the sulfur attracts Mo atoms more effectively than Co due to the large electronegativity of sulfur atoms. The edges and corners of the hollow cobalt sulfide extend outward and contract to the void, respectively. On the other hand, the composites form regular structures owing to the effect of the nickel foam substrate. Therefore, when molybdenum sulfide content reaches a certain level, the prepared composite material forms a 3D starfish shaped heterojunction because of the combined effect of molybdenum sulfide content and nickel foam substrate, where the nickel foam (NF) plays an important role in the formation of a 3D starfish-like structure with the MoS2 nanosheets grown in the angular direction of the hollow CoS polyhedron shown in Fig. 1 (a and b). For comparison, the ZIF-67/NF precursor and its derivative hollow CoS were synthesized, as shown in Figs. S1 and S2. It can be observed that the powder ZIF-67, ZIF-67/NF precursor, hollow CoS and hollow CoS/NF feature a regular dodecahedron morphology. The results indicate that the nickel foam support substrate has no effect on the morphology of the precursor and its derivatives. In order to further compare the effect of the NF support material on the composite catalyst morphology, the ZIF-67 powder and CoS powder were modified by MoS2, respectively. Nevertheless, when the powder ZIF-67 is decorated by MoS2, it can be clearly observed in Fig. S3 that ZIF-67 is coated with MoS2 nanosheets into a spherical structure, and the nanosheets are densely packed. Moreover, the powder MoS2/CoS composite keeps the hollow structure, and the stacking between MoS2 nanosheets becomes loose as revealed in Fig. S4(a and b) and the inset in Fig. S4(b). The above discussions illustrate the important role of nickel foam on the morphology of MoS2/CoS heterojunctions. Furthermore, to demonstrate the effect of different components on the catalytic performance, a series of MoS2/CoS/NF heterojunction composite materials with different feeding ratios of MoS2 were prepared. When the feeding ratio of MoS2 and the precursor of CoS is 0.5, the 0.5-MoS2/CoS/NF composite maintains the polyhedron morphology displayed in Fig. S5. While increasing the feeding ratio of MoS2 and the precursor of CoS to 1, the 1-MoS2/CoS/NF material looks like a starfish structure, and the MoS2 nanosheets grown in the angular direction of the hollow CoS polyhedron are observed in Fig. S6. However, the size of the stacked MoS2 nanosheets is larger for 1-MoS2/CoS/NF compared to the mentioned above 2-MoS2/CoS/NF (Fig. 1a and b). By further increase of the feeding ratio of MoS2 and the precursor of CoS to 3, the 3-MoS2/CoS/NF nanowires that form enoki mushroom-like structures are built from stacks of nanosheets shown in Fig. S7. These results show that the stacked MoS2 nanosheets are denser for 3-MoS2/CoS/NF than the above mentioned 2-MoS2/CoS/NF structures. The above discussion suggests that the 2-MoS2/CoS/NF has a better topology for electrocatalytic applications. Further, the X-ray diffraction (XRD) was used to analyze the crystal structure of the synthesized heterojunction catalysts. For comparison, the XRD pattern of the only CoS/NF is presented in Fig. S8, which reveals the CoS (JCPDS No. 65-3418) and NF peaks. As shown in Fig. 1(c), we can see that the 2-MoS2/CoS/NF mainly contains CoS (JCPDS No. 65-3418) and MoS2 (JCPDS No. 37-1492) [22]. The main peaks at 30.5°, 35.2°and 54.8° corresponded to the (100), (101) and (110) of the CoS phase, respectively. Meanwhile, the peaks at 14.3°, 32.8°, 37.5° and 58.3° are indexed to the (002), (100), (103), and (110) of the MoS2 phase. The result indicates that the MoS2/CoS/NF composite material was successfully prepared. Besides, it can be found that the peak intensity of CoS does not decrease with the increase of MoS2 feeding ratio. Particularly, it can be seen that the peak of CoS increases with the increase of MoS2 feeding ratio around 30.5. This result indicates that MoS2 did not simply grow on the surface, but CoS also participated in the reaction and changed its morphology. Moreover, the high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images of 2-MoS2/CoS/NF are presented in Fig.1(d), and the clear lattice fringes with the spacing of 0.27 and 0.29 nm can be observed in the Fig. 1(e), which are attributed to the (100) and (100) crystal planes of MoS2 and CoS, respectively. The result is consistent with the XRD results. In addition, it reveals the tight contact between the CoS (100) with the d-space of 0.29 nm and MoS2 (100) phases with the d-space of 0.27 nm, and it proves the formation of heterojunctions as evidenced by the well-resolved lattice fringes. The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns. (Fig. 1f) suggest the rings formed to correspond to the crystal planes of MoS2 and CoS. Further, the SEM mapping of 2-MoS2/CoS/NF in the low-resolution mode indicates that the S, Mo and Co elements distribute uniformly on the surface of the heterojunction catalyst shown in Fig. 1(g). The 2-MoS2/CoS/NF composite was further confirmed by the XPS to study the valence state of the constituent elements as presented in Fig. 2 . The survey spectrum of the 2-MoS2/CoS/NF heterojunction is displayed in Fig. 2(a), which present the Co 2p, Mo 2p and S 2p peaks. In the Co 2p spectra shown in Fig. 2(b), the binding energies at 794.3 eV and 779.2 eV are ascribed to Co3+ 2p 1/2 and Co3+ 2p 3/2, and the peaks at 800.5 eV and 782.4 eV correspond to Co2+ 2p 1/2 and Co2+ 2p 3/2 states, respectively [23]. The Mo 3d spectra of 2-MoS2/CoS/NF displayed two obvious peaks at about 231.9 and 228.7 eV in Fig. 2(c), which are assigned to Mo 3d 3/2 components of Mo-S bonding in MoS2 and Mo 3d 5/2, respectively. Meanwhile, the peaks at 234.0 and 225.8 eV correspond to Mo+6 coming from the sample oxidation in air and S 2s in MoS2, respectively [28]. For the S 2p spectra, (Fig. 2d), the peaks located at 162.9 and 161.6 eV are attributed to S 2p 1/2 and S 2p 3/2, in the agreememt with the previously reported sulfide materials [29]. In addition, the peak at 168.9 eV corresponds to oxidized sulfur species, which may be caused by the oxygen absorbed on 2-MoS2/CoS/NF surface in the air [30]. Besides, the BET was measured by separating the catalyst from NF for MoS2/NF, CoS/NF and 2-MoS2/CoS/NF. In Fig. 2(e), the 2-MoS2/CoS/NF has a large specific surface area (43 m2 g−1) than those of the MoS2/NF (28 m2 g−1) and CoS/NF (24 m2 g−1) shown in Fig. S9. The pore size diameter further reveals that the 2-MoS2/CoS/NF has micro-mesoporous structure in Fig. 2(f). Consequently, the 2-MoS2/CoS/NF heterojunction has loose surface topography and porous channel structure that can facilitate mass transfer and electron transfer compared to the MoS2/NF and the CoS/NF samples. 3.2 Electrocatalytic performance for HER and OER The HER activity of the as-prepared products is further measured in a typical three-electrode device with 1.0 M KOH electrolyte. The findings about the as-prepared samples on the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) are analyzed and shown in Figs. 3 (a), S10 and S11. It is observed that the LSV of the 2-MoS2/CoS/NF exhibits the smaller overpotentials of 67 mV at 10 mA cm−2, which exceed the performance of the single component CoS/NF, MoS2/NF and its counterparts (Fig. 3b), is close to the commercial Pt/C electrode (52 mV), as well as surpass most of the recently reported metal sulfides in Fig. 3(c) [31–40], demonstrating the improved HER activity of the 2-MoS2/CoS/NF. In order to achieve a deeper understanding of the HER kinetic mechanism, we computed the Tafel slopes derived from the LSV. The slopes equal to 56, 48, 106 and 125 mV dec−1 for the 2-MoS2/CoS/NF, Pt/C/NF, MoS2/NF and hollow CoS/NF electrodes displayed in Fig. 3(d), respectively. Thus, the 2-MoS2/CoS/NF has a fast HER process and outstanding activity, which approaches to Pt/C and can be ascribed to the heterogeneous interface effect and the intricate multi-channel structure. Further, the long-term stability of the 2-MoS2/CoS/NF is assessed by the chronoamperometry at the current density of 10 mA cm−2. The result indicates that the 2-MoS2/CoS/NF electrode is very robust and reveals negligible degradation after 22 h continuous operation (Fig. 3e), and the LSV measured before and after the 3000 cycles in Fig. 3(f), confirming the excellent long-term stability. The electrochemical reaction kinetics is commonly evaluated using electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS). As shown in Fig. S12, the EIS value of the CoS/NF, MoS2/NF and 2-MoS2/CoS/NF samples were tested. The smaller R ct reveals a faster charge transfer rate and good electrical conductivity in the electrochemical process. It can be observed that the R ct of CoS/NF, MoS2/NF and 2-MoS2/CoS/NF are 258, 136 and 80 Ω, respectively. The EIS results indicate that the 2-MoS2/CoS/NF can promote the electrochemical process. The electrochemically active area (ECSA) of the hollow CoS/NF, MoS2/NF and 2-MoS2/CoS/NF electrodes were evaluated by the double-layer capacitance (C dl) because of their proportional relationship. The values of the C dl were calculated by using the CV curves of the HER in Fig. S13(a–c). In Fig. S13(d), the calculated C dl value of 2-MoS2/CoS/NF is 11.4 mF cm2, which is larger than for the hollow CoS/NF (4.2 mF cm2), MoS2/NF (6.7 mF cm2). The relatively higher C dl value means that the 2-MoS2/CoS/NF has a larger electrochemically active area, thus enhancing the HER performance. Furthermore, the SEM and XPS of the 2-MoS2/CoS/NF catalyst are characterized after HER. It is noted that the 2-MoS2/CoS/NF heterojunction still keeps the 3D flower shape structure in the SEM image after HER measurement as displayed in Fig. S14(a). The result shows that the morphology of the 3D flower shape structure is not destroyed during HER process. Besides, the XPS spectra of the 2-MoS2/CoS/NF are further tested to study the changes of elemental state before and after the HER. For the Co 2p spectrum, the peaks are negligible shifts change compared to the before HER in Fig. S14(b). However, the Mo 3d located at the 232.4 and 235.5 eV exhibits positive shifts phenomenon in Fig. S14(c), which can be assigned to Mo 3d 3/2 and Mo6+, manifesting that a small amount of MoO3 is formed after the HER [41]. Additionally, in the case of S 2p in Fig. S14(d), the peak at 161.0 eV has a shift of about 0.6 eV to the lower binding energy compared to the S 2p before HER, confirming that the sulfur electrons have transferred in Mo phase, which can be ascribed to the main active site for HER process. Moreover, the OER capability of the 2-MoS2/CoS/NF was also studied in the same electrolyte. As shown in Fig. S15, it can be found that the oxidation current densities of the catalysts are larger when the sweep rate goes from negative to positive. To eliminate the possible contributions of oxidation current densities to OER, the LSV curves were recorded by sweeping from high to low potentials [42]. As shown in Fig. 4 (a), it is noticed that a plateau between ∼1.2 V and 1.3 V appeared in the LSV curve, which may be caused by the redox oxidation of Ni/Co species [43]. The catalytic performance of the commercial RuO2/NF, hollow CoS/NF, MoS2/NF as well as its counterparts are performed for comparison. As a result, the OER catalytic activity of the 2-MoS2/CoS/NF electrode increase obviously according to the LSV curves as shown in Figs. 4(a), S16 and S17. These data reveal the lowest overpotential of 207 mV for 2-MoS2/CoS/NF at 10 mA cm−2, which is much better compared to RuO2/NF, its counterparts (Fig. 4b) and the recent research reports shown in Fig. 4(c) [31–37,44–47]. As can be seen from the performance test results, the powder-type catalysts show a sharp performance difference in Figs. S10 and S16, but the catalysts on NF (Figs. 3a and 4a) do not show that much difference for both HER and OER performance. This happens because the powder-type catalysts tend to fall off during testing. In addition, the electrocatalysts often bind to polymers resulting in partial burial of the active site. For the catalysts on NF with uniform growth, the content of molybdenum sulfide is no longer the main determinant of the catalytic activity when the content of sulfide and cobalt sulfide reaches the optimum ratio. Therefore, the 2-MoS2/CoS/NF sample shows the optimal HER and OER activities than its counterparts. The Tafel slopes of the 2-MoS2/CoS/NF is 65 mV dec− 1 as displayed in Fig. 4(d), which is the smallest among the values obtained for hollow CoS/NF (116 mV dec− 1), MoS2/NF (99 mV dec− 1), and RuO2/NF (78 mV dec− 1). It indicates that the 2-MoS2/CoS/NF as an active electrocatalyst exhibits the fastest OER kinetics process. Furthermore, the 2-MoS2/CoS/NF is very stable and has almost ignorable deterioration of performance after 22 h test displayed in Fig. 4(e), which reveals the excellent long-term durability. In addition, it is found that the LSV of the 2-MoS2/CoS/NF shows almost no deviation after 3000 cycles measurement in Fig. 4(f), suggesting that the as-prepared 2-MoS2/CoS/NF has excellent stability in alkali environment. In addition, the CV curves for OER of the hollow CoS/NF, MoS2/NF and 2-MoS2/CoS/NF electrodes are presented in Fig. S18(a–c). The C dl values were assessed by CV curves in Fig. S18(d). It can be noted that the calculated C dl value of 2-MoS2/CoS/NF is 13.8 mF cm2, and it is larger than the hollow CoS/NF (1.1 mF cm2), MoS2/NF (8.3 mF cm2). In other words, the 2-MoS2/CoS/NF with a higher Cdl value has a larger electrochemically active area, resulting in superior OER activity. Moreover, the morphology of the 2-MoS2/CoS/NF hardly changed after OER reactions as displayed in Fig. S19, further demonstrating the 2-MoS2/CoS/NF catalyst is stable. The high-resolution XPS spectra of Mo 3d at 235.5 eV correspond to oxidized-Mo (Mo6+) in Fig. S20(a), suggesting that the molybdenum is oxidized after the OER process. The peaks of the S 2p spectrum shift toward lower binding energy in Fig. S20(b), while the characteristic peaks of the Co 2p at 788.2 eV indicate that some Co is oxidized to form oxides/hydroxides of cobalt in Fig. S20(c). This result reveals that the surface of the 2-MoS2/CoS/NF is oxidized to produce the CoO/CoOOH species expected as the active site in OER catalytic process, which is similar to the prior studies [48]. Clearly, a peak at 530.6 eV in the O 1s spectrum suggests that the metal-oxide/hydroxyl is generated during the OER process in Fig. S20(d) [49]. The above conclusions reveal that the metal-oxide/hydroxides not just accelerate the rapid mass transport and electrons transfer, but also improve the electrocatalytic activity. 3.3 Electrocatalytic performance for overall water splitting We further examined the water splitting performance of 2-MoS2/CoS/NF as anode and cathode under conditions close to practical applications. For overall water splitting, a two-electrode device is fabricated, simultaneously using 2-MoS2/CoS/NF as the anode and cathode electrocatalysts (Fig. 5 a). It is observed that the 2-MoS2/CoS/NF electrode just needs a low voltage of 1.517 V at 10 mA cm−2 shown in Fig. 5(b). Compared to the previously reported electrocatalysts [50–57] in Fig. 5(c), this system shows evident superiority. Additionally, the long-term durability of the 2-MoS2/CoS/NF catalyst for overall water splitting is presented in Fig. 5(d). It can be found that the current density is negligible loss after continuous operation for 22 h. Overall, the unique morphology and heterojunction of 2-MoS2/CoS/NF can facilitate charge transfer and improve the water splitting performance. 3.4 First-principles calculations In order to gain insights into the catalytic performance of HER and OER, we explored the relationship between the electronic structure and the intrinsic catalytic activity by DFT calculations. As displayed in Fig. 6 (a–c), the optimized atomic structure model of the CoS, MoS2 and 2-MoS2/CoS, and the corresponding electron localization function (ELF) are presented. Meanwhile, the valence electron distribution character of the catalytic surface is studied via ELF. It is observed that the ELF of the CoS and MoS2 is about 0.7 around the S site, which signifies a strongly localized and little electron distribution, respectively. While, as for 2-MoS2/CoS, the ELF iso-value of around 0.5 is found S site in the interface between MoS2 and CoS, distribution compared to the CoS and MoS2. To further understand the electronic suggesting that the 2-MoS2/CoS heterojunction has a better delocalized electron structure of the catalysts, the density of states (DOS) is computed in Fig. 6(d), which suggests that the 2-MoS2/CoS is farther from the Fermi level than MoS2 and CoS. This is because of the coupling of the d-orbital electrons of Co and Mo with the p-orbitals of S atoms, thus increasing the degree of electron delocalization. Besides, the OER process relies on the formation of *OH, *O, *OOH and *OO (*denotes the active site). In general, catalysts with lower overpotential tend to have higher catalytic activity. The adsorption configuration of the oxygen-containing intermediates on CoS, MoS2 and 2-MoS2/CoS catalysts are presented in Figs. S21–S23. Meanwhile, Fig. 6(e) suggests that the free energy of each reaction step of CoS, MoS2 and 2-MoS2/CoS during the OER process is upward (U = 0 V). Furthermore, at an equilibrium potential (U = 1.23 V), the formation and release of *OOH is endothermic on the 2-MoS2/CoS active sites. Nevertheless, it is not thermodynamically beneficial to the CoS and MoS2 sites. For the 2-MoS2/CoS active sites, the transformation of *OOH to O2 is the limiting step due to its largest energy change during the OER process. The limiting energy change of 2-MoS2/CoS is 0.56 eV, which is lower compared to CoS (1.16 eV) and MoS2 (1.09 eV) revealed in Fig. 6(f). The result suggests the effective OER reactive activation of 2-MoS2/CoS because of the existence of heterogeneous interfaces. Moreover, for the HER process, the H* adsorbed at CoS, MoS2 and 2-MoS2/CoS are displayed in Figs. S24 and 6(g). The 2-MoS2/CoS has a free energy change of 0.29 eV, which is smaller than the CoS (2.28 eV) and MoS2 (1.98 eV), confirming that the 2-MoS2/CoS has excellent HER activity. These results suggest that the interface coupling between MoS2 and CoS phases improves electron delocalization in 2-MoS2/CoS and thus boosts the HER and OER catalytic activities of 2-MoS2/CoS. In addition, the adsorption and dissociation energy of water for HER in alkaline solution are further calculated to study the change of the energy barrier during the HER. The transition state (TS) of the hollow CoS, MoS2 and 2-MoS2/CoS as well as the corresponding H2O splitting models are presented in Fig. S25. The results show that the transition state energy barrier of 2-MoS2/CoS has the lowest value compared to the hollow CoS and MoS2 observed in Fig. S26. Therefore, the 2-MoS2/CoS heterojunction is most conducive to HER process. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have successfully prepared bifunctional electrocatalysts via the introduction of nickel foam support substrate to obtain a 3D heterojunction structure by room temperature growth, vulcanization process and subsequent hydrothermal reaction. To optimize the electrocatalytic performance, the effects of the feeding ratio of different MoS2 on the morphology and the catalytic performance for HER, OER and overall water splitting have been investigated. The optimized 2-MoS2/CoS/NF shows excellent HER and OER performance characterized by a lower overpotential of 67 and 207 mV at 10 mA cm−2. Moreover, the 2-MoS2/CoS/NF just needs a low voltage of 1.517 V during overall water splitting at 10 mA cm−2 in 1 M KOH, which obviously facilitates the water splitting process and achieves outstanding electrocatalytic activity. DFT calculations suggest that the improved electrocatalytic activity of 2-MoS2/CoS/NF can be attributed to the heterointerface between MoS2 and CoS, which can improve the adsorption of intermediates during the HER and OER process, and further promote the kinetics of water splitting. This work provides a novel strategy to fabricate advanced heterojunction bifunctional electrocatalysts for future energy storage and conversion devices. coredata.dc:description: The utilization of non-noble metal catalysts with robust and highly efficient electrocatalytic activity for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) are extremely important for the large-scale implementation of renewable energy devices. Integration of bifunctional electrocatalysts on both anode and cathode electrodes remains a significant challenge. Herein, we report on a novel and facile strategy to construct the ordered and aligned MoS2 nanosheet-encapsulated metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) derived hollow CoS polyhedron, in-situ grown on a nickel foam (NF). The starfish-like MoS2/CoS/NF heterojunctions were formed due to the ordered growth of the material caused by NF substrate. The optimized 2-MoS2/CoS/NF heterojunction exhibits robust bifunctional electrocatalytic activity with a low overpotential of 67 and 207 mV toward the HER and OER at 10 mA cm−2, and the long-term stability, which exceeds most of the reported bifunctional electrocatalysts. Such high electrocatalytic performance arises due to the synergistic effect between the MoS2 and CoS phases across the interface, the abundant active sites, as well as the hierarchical pore framework, which collectively enhance the mass and electron transfer during the reactions. The work provides a promising approach to fabricating bifunctional catalysts with custom-designed heterojunctions and remarkable performance for applications in electrochemical energy devices and related areas.
